values: *snort* *chokes on coffee* *coughs a lot* ...Seriously? Seriously? Oh, come on. Ex-thief, here. Not the greatest ex-thief ever, either. I was working on my third strike--for a crime that I did not in any way commit, thank you very much, though it really should have been for the act of burglary I was attempting, not the stupid frickin' Good Samaritan act I pulled that landed me in that whole mess--what was I talking about? Oh yeah. I was working on my third strike when I, uh, I guess you could say I flipped sides. Prison, by the way? So not pleasant. So, um, yeah. Like I said, now I'm not the one getting arrested--most of the time--I'm the one arresting other people instead. Or letting Hobbes do that. He likes to put the cuffs on people. Oh jeez, not like that, get your minds out of the gutter. It was really weird at first, y'know? It still is, sometimes, but at least I get to use a lot of the same skill sets. For various reasons. *looks shifty* ...my life is so weird.

Uh, when you say run, are we talking literally or metaphorically here? Because, me, I excel at metaphorical running. I am the king at running away from things. My family. Responsibilities. My life. Whatever isn't working for me at the moment, my first response a lot of the time is to run first, figure it all out later. Okay, these days, I usually don't get the chance to run very far. Robert E. Hobbes is a lot more tenacious in that department than Kevin or my aunt and uncle ever were. But even Kev always found me, eventually, and pulled me out of whatever hidey hole I'd found for myself. But, metaphorically, it's been a while since I ran like that. I...I don't need to so much anymore. Or I've gotten better coping skills, I'm not sure. I mean, when everything in your life is hell anyway, there isn't much point in running, is there? If we're talking literally running, though, that was this morning. First after a perp, then from a perp. The guy had a gun. I should have expected the gun, but I didn't, and there it was. One of these days, Hobbes is gonna have to give me weapons training. And the Fatman is gonna have to authorize me a gun. I'm not carrying a hammer around all the time, man.

Badly, mostly.

...what, you want details? I tend to yell a lot. Just ask Hobbes. (Not that he doesn't do his fair share of yelling in stressful situations either.) I run away rather than try to cope. (Sometimes, running away *is* coping.) I go crazy. (Okay, that's not so much by choice. Most of the time.) I steal stuff. (Or at least, I used to. Now I just, like, swipe Eberts' stapler when he's not looking, and that's not so much a response to pressure as a way to *create* pressure because holy crap, Eberts does not like people messing with his office supplies.) These are the ways I respond to pressure.

...Okay, I respond in other ways too. Sometimes, they are even productive and get the job done. But, y'know? My life is pressure. Literally; I can feel it building in my head every few days, ticking away like the timer on an ugly blood-red bomb, if I don't get the switch that freezes the timer. It never quite stops it, but at least I can get that short reprieve.

It's a stupid question anyway. How would you *expect* somebody to respond to pressure?

I would just say no to drugs, but I kinda can't. Because the alternative is worse, and that just sucks. I usually say no to foreign governments who only want me for my gland, secret organizations, crazy people, and bad guys. Or, well, I usually try to. These days. I didn't always say no to the bad guys; hell, I was a thief, I suppose technically I was a bad guy. And trying is not always good enough; I will not list all the secret organizations, foreign governments, and crazy people who have in the past couple years gotten their claws in me. Sometimes literally, but...that's really not worth going into. I say no to pretty women a lot these days. I don't really want to talk about that. It's depressing. I should probably say no less to the Fatman. He is, theoretically, my boss. I should definitely say no to Hobbes more; the crap he gets me into sometimes, I swear--okay, okay, he's reading over my shoulder and telling me I'm the one who gets us into crap all the time, not him, whatever, we should both say no to each other more often. I don't say no to Claire or Alex Monroe. I know better.

Have you ever sold out? *runs hand through hair* That's, uh...that's a tougher question to answer than I expected. I mean, I guess it might depend on your definition of sell-out. Merriam-Webster, they're pretty circumspect in their definition: one who sells out. They don't provide any connotative associations with that definition, do they? The point where I sold out is when I gave my brother permission to stick a gland in my head that would turn me invisible, all so that I would get out of my prison sentence. Which shouldn't have been my sentence in the first place, and when I *really* sold out was after my brother died and I went to work for his stupid Agency, but that was all blackmail from the Official anyway because if I didn't work for him I wouldn't get the counteragent that would stop me from going crazy every few days. See? It all depends on your definition. Your context, maybe. Some days, I really don't even feel like a sell-out. Talk about something cheerful. Oh, thank god, something *nice* for a change. Right, something cheerful-- Aw, crap, surely I've got *some*thing cheerful I can say? The other night after work, Hobbes and I were heading out to grab a bite somewhere, and we ran into Claire in the elevator. We invited her along, and she said yes--she doesn't, most of the time, keeping (haha) herself to herself--so we ended up going somewhere a bit nicer than what Hobbes had probably been planning. (Seriously, I think he goes out of his way to find the grossest dives in this city. He probably thinks it's character-building or something.) Italian place, low-key but with the candles on the tables and everything. The food was really good, the wine tasted just right--and I'm way more of a beer guy than a wine guy--and we maybe accidentally helped shut the place down because we didn't notice what time it was. It was--it was really, really good. Sometimes I worry about my social life, or complete lack thereof what with the gland and all, and we all spend waaaay too much of our lives in each other's pockets every day as it is. And there's been this whole--uh, thing--between Bobby, Claire and I since a certain incident a few weeks back...actually, a couple incidents in the past few months...well, yeah, it's maybe been a tiny bit awkward. Sometimes. Between the three of us. But we just sat and talked, and laughed, and ate, and drank, and it was like we were all three perfectly normal human beings. For us, that's pretty awesome. I'm hoping we can do it again sometime. Sometime.

...the hell? What makes you think I cry? 'Cause I don't. I yell, I holler, I even on occasion scream in pain--hey, you would too if you had the occasional needle jammed into the back of your head or something--but I do not cry.

...okay. Okay, okay, okay. I cried when my mom died, when I was a little kid. I might've cried when my uncle died, but I think--I don't think I did, by that point. I cried when my brother died, briefly, because I had no time because I had to run away before a bastard of a villain caught me and used me, and I've cried at his grave since then. I, uh, I might have cried or almost cried sometimes when I thought Bobby or Claire was dead.

That's what makes me cry, okay? People I care about dying. That's a pretty good reason to cry, don't you think?

It's a stupid question anyway.

My name is Darien Fawkes, they call me Furious D-- ...yeah, okay, nobody actually calls me Furious D. Nobody has ever called me Furious D. You have no idea how much this disappoints me. I've never really been one for nicknames, you know? Hobbes likes to call me things related to the invisibility gland, or, well, call the gland itself nicknames--the 6 Million Dollar Gland is his personal favorite, no matter how much I tell him it's old now, find a new one--but as a kid, as a teen, I never really got too many nicknames attached to me. Other than "Really tall freak" or "The dude with the crazy hair," stuff like that, and I...don't feel a need to count those. As for Furious D...what can I say? I was bored one day at work. I'm tellin' ya, if I'm not working on a case? I have nothing to do. Other than paperwork, writing reports or something, but I leave all that to Hobbsey and his dyslexia. One of these days, I swear I'm gonna end up watching soaps with the Fatman and Eberts. Crap.

Okay, this might sound a little weird, but I used to love to sleep.

I know, right?  I know you're thinking, "Dude, you were a thief."  So I loved to sleep during the day.  There's nothing quite like going to bed in that grey hour just before the sun comes up, and then sleeping through sunrise.  Seriously.  I loved cracking an eye open, blinking at the sun, then turning around and going back to sleep.

I don't do that anymore.

For one thing, I work "normal" hours pretty regularly now.  They don't allow for much sleeping past noon; Hobbes would probably knock down my door down if I tried.  I've had to pay for enough damages from that sort of thing.

For another, I just don't like sleeping anymore.  I have too many nightmares, too many memories that have become nightmares.  I wake up more often yelling or holding a wrench than I do peacefully anymore.

There's probably something ironic there.  I got better sleep when I was a criminal.

I've actually thought about this sometimes, you know? If my eight-year-old self could stumble across me, over twenty years later, what would he say? And the first thing I usually think is, "Dude, what the hell is wrong with you?" I hadn't started snatching and grabbing when I was eight. Hadn't met Liz yet, hadn't turned into some kind of stereotypical disaffected teenage youth yet. I was still innocent enough and occasionally happy enough, despite mom dying and my older brother being a jerk and my aunt and uncle not understanding me at all. I could still play and have fun, sometimes even with other kids my age. But, I mean, kids, they don't get adults, any more than most adults can understand kids. So why would it matter what the eight-year-old version of me thought of now-me? He wouldn't know. I did use to imagine being a secret agent. Along with astronaut and fireman and scientist so maybe I'd get along with my brother and uncle. So maybe that factor, along with my ability to turn invisible, would make me look cool. You know what's really pathetic about this whole question? The fact that I'm worried about appearing "cool" to my younger self. Jeez.

"The problem, of course, was that people did not seem to understand the difference between right and wrong. They needed to be reminded about this, because if you left it to them to work it out themselves, they would never bother. They would just find what was best for them, and then they would call that the right thing. That's how most people thought." --Alexander McCall Smith, The No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency Hey, man, I've been there. I have followed the path of least resistance most of my life. It was easy. It worked for me. That's how I ended up above-average in high school; that's how I ended up in my petty little life of crime. I didn't have to think too much about right or wrong back then. I mean, I knew what I did was legally wrong, but--so what, right? The people I was robbing, they all had insurance to cover the cost of the items I took, crap like that; it was practically victimless crimes. (I say something like that to Hobbes or the Keep, and they just look at me. Jeez.) These days, these days I'm stuck with right and wrong. I have to look at it every day, every time the Official threatens to cut me off from the counteragent, every time Arnaud pops his slimy little head in to say hello, every time Chrysalis comes up with a new plan for world domination. Every time I feel the quicksilver madness itching in the back of my head, I feel the urge to steal itching in my fingers. Every day. Right and wrong. They're choices, and I can pretty much guarantee you there are no guarantees, but every day I'm reminded about the differences between the two. And about the fact that I have to choose.

Heh.  Uh...yeah.  Ten years ago I was flunking out of college--okay, not really, but apathy had distinctly set in by that point and I was getting ready to drop out--and, uh, perfecting my skills in my chosen career.  

I say chosen.  It wasn't so much something deliberately thought out as something I'd fallen into a few years before.  I had a natural talent.  And...it was easy.

A lot of things used to seem a lot easier than they were.  My chosen career, for example.  And also?  Natural talent only gets you so far.

So ten years ago I was a thief.  Five years ago I was a thief; hell, yesterday I stole some files out of an office I shouldn't have been in, all in the name of a case Hobbes, Monroe and I were working on.  The more things change, the more they stay the same, right?

But, that said, I have way better hair now than I did then.

I've got this old lock pick set-- What? Former thief, here, I've got more than one lock pick set. But this one's my favorite. Liz gave it to me, years and years ago, and she'd had it for a long time herself. The metal's worn down with where the fingers have held it, but she took good care of the tools before she gave them to me. I still take good care of them, make sure they don't get rusty. Thief's only as good as his tools, Liz sometimes said. (Hobbes pretends not to know I still hold onto stuff like this. Claire may or may not honestly believe I finally got rid of my old tools after the last time I ran into Liz. I...try not to mention it in front of either of them.) I don't have a whole lot left from my childhood. Pictures, and maybe if I wanted to salvage something from Aunt Celia's house--but what? What would be the point? At least I can still find a use for my lock pick set.

Uh, hello? That's a really stupid question. I've forgotten it, how the hell would I know or remember it? Yeah, yeah, okay, okay, I'm being too literal, right? Right? So what have I forgotten. I've forgotten all that stuff you forget from when you were a kid, all the basic stuff like what your favorite food was and how a typical day in school went and the bigger stuff too, the stuff that didn't make a whole lot of sense because you didn't understand it because you were too young and didn't have the-the experience, or the context, or anything. I've forgotten all that, yeah, just like most people probably have. Some of it maybe I can piece back together, figure out from whatever fuzzy memories I have, but a lot of it is just--gone. I've forgotten the important stuff too. I know it. I don't remember what my mom's lips felt like when she kissed me good night. I don't remember if my dad played with me before he left, if he made me laugh. Sometimes, I barely remember a time my brother and I got along. Not all the time. I don't forget that all the time. I guess that's something, at least.

Heh. Uh. That's a...question. Um. How far wouldn't I be willing to go? Because, you know, I've done some pretty crazy stuff to prove my point. I let my brother's memory RNA take me over once just so I could get him to take the gland out of my brain. I injected myself with a substance I knew was lethal just to prove to Bobby that friendship meant more to him than, than dying alone and super-freaking-intelligent. I stole millions of dollars just to piss off the Fatman and Arnaud. And possibly because I was having a really bad day. Um. You know? When I think about it, I'm kind of a crazy guy. Even without the red eyes and loss of ego in favor of id. (I never was much of a Freudian, you know. But I digress.) The craziest one had to be Hobbes, though. I knew taking that shot would kill me, kill me; with the other stuff death was only a (very strong) possibility. But I also knew Bobby Hobbes would never bail on his partner. And he didn't. And, hey. I proved my point.

Okay, let me just start off by saying I am the king of hiding. I mean, ex-thief here, not to mention the original Invisible Man. I can fricking hide from anything. And anybody. So long as they're not wearing thermal glasses of some kind. Now, that, of course, is pretty much all a lie. Well, not all of it. I mean, I am really good at hiding. And way too many people these days are wearing thermal. But I also suck at it. And I can't hide from myself. I've tried a lot. Wouldn't look at my past, wouldn't look at how I ended up where I am today. Wouldn't admit that I had any choices. But it's a lot harder to hide when you've got a gland in your head that will turn you insane and raging every few days if you don't get a particular drug. Way to make me take responsibility there, right. Yeah, usually I'm still blaming it for all the crap that happens to me--and well I should, don't get me wrong--but, I mean, it's me. I have to do something about myself. I don't get to hide as much as I used to. The reasons why suck, but...the end result might not be a bad thing. Just don't tell Hobbes I said that.

I've seen Bobby Hobbes dreaming. The occasional stake-out where he catches a snooze while I and/or Monroe watch; once or twice where we had to keep each other in sight at all times. (He says I snore, which is a load of crap; he's the one who snores.) I've seen him have a nightmare exactly once. He woke me up, actually. He was crashing at my place while his apartment was being fumigated, and I heard this weird noise coming from my couch. Now, me, I've become a light sleeper. Comes from not waking up too many times when I should have, comes from waking up badly more times than I care to count. So I woke up and I was just gonna yell at Bobby to shut up and quit snoring, when I realized what I was hearing and where it was coming from, but...it still didn't sound quite right. He was twitching a little, and it--it wasn't exactly a moan, or a groan, or a sigh, but somewhere in between. He wasn't talking, saying anything I could call words, and his hands kept bunching up into fists. I was standing there staring at him, trying to decide if I could risk waking him--Bobby Hobbes wakes up mean--when he woke himself up, sitting up with a yell. I've never asked him what the dream was about. He didn't glare at me, exactly, when he became aware of his surroundings, but he just--looked at me. And I went back to bed. After I got him a glass of water. I've never asked him, and I don't think I want to.

"Mediocrity knows nothing higher than itself, but talent instantly recognizes genius." -Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, The Valley of Fear Genius? You want to talk about genius? Well, let me tell you what my old friend Thomas Carlyle had to say on the topic--"Genius means the transcendent capacity of taking trouble." Or Seneca, now Seneca had something interesting to say about genius--"There is no great genius without a tincture of madness." Though Elizabeth Barrett Browning might have put it best when she asked, "Since when was genius found respectable?" You don't throw quotes at me without expecting something back. Now, I've known my fair share of geniuses. My brother was a genius, my uncle might've been too. Claire is definitely a genius. Bobby Hobbes there, he was a genius for a while, though it didn't last. Maybe that's where his true genius lay; he gave it up because knowledge without friendship wasn't worth it. My brother was a genius. He let his work, his drive, consume him. Me--I think I'm talented. Maybe not always at what I want to be talented at, maybe not always at what is considered respectable (I think I've been hanging out with the Keeper too long). And I can still kick back and enjoy myself. Most of the time. Kevin died because he was a genius. If something that is supposed to be a gift gets you killed the way he died, then...I think I'd rather take the mediocrity. But Kev--he couldn't have been anything different. And me? I couldn't save him. Perhaps, in the end, the Earl of Lytton's supposed last words say it best: Genius does what it must, talent does what it can.

Oh, man.  First girl I had a crush on, right?  I mean, first *real* crush, you know, not "gee, X actress is really hot on that TV show" or whatever.  Seventh grade, she sat in front of me in science class.  She had really nice hair.  Long, in a ponytail all the time.  I think she might've had braces too, but, I mean, how would I remember?  I sat behind her all the time.

So, yeah, I had a crush on her, right.  I didn't tell anybody; why the hell would I?  It would just be embarrassing.  But people found out anyway, somehow--I don't know, maybe I was a dork and mooned after her by her locker or something.  My classmates started making fun of me, she said she wouldn't be caught dead seen with me, and the next day she sat somewhere else in science class.

That?  That is a really crappy way for a first crush to end, lemme tell you.

I always hate it when I get to that part of any new--acquaintance. I never seem able to avoid it coming up, either. The show and tell portion. Why can't I just be some super-cool, super-smooth, super-mysterious secret agent? There should be some kind of compensation for the kind of crap I have to go through every day including working with the Fatman, Eberts, the Keeper, Monroe, and Hobbes when he's off his meds. I should be able to walk off into the night, or the sunset, or whatever cliche you want to use, with everybody else none-the-wiser about what or who the hell I am. But no. It never seems to work like that. Kate, Allianora, Mai-Lin, the psycho-acupuncturist Charlene...I'm just going around, minding my own business, doing my job or maybe in so much pain I can't do my job, and--bam. Something happens, something comes up, and suddenly they know I'm invisible. Okay, so some of them already knew I could turn invisible before I did it. Whatever. It's not like I had to confirm it for them. It's not like anybody has to-has to see that. I hate it, okay? No, I'm not overly fond of secrets, but I like having my privacy. It's bad enough that the Official uses me, the Keeper prods and pokes me, Hobbes lectures me. Sometimes I want to get away and be something--somebody--other than the Invisible Man.

...So many people have wanted to redeem me. You know that? My brother was probably the first; or maybe a teacher--there were plenty of teachers who thought they could, I dunno, show me the light or something. My brother was probably the worst, though, until he gave up on me. Actually, his giving up on me might have hurt a little more. They were all trying to make me a Better Man or some crap like that, completely missing the point that I was perfectly happy the way I was. That I didn't need to be redeemed. Okay, how I made my living was not, uh, the most socially respectable thing to do, but it's not like half the crap people can get away with legally these days is responsible or morally good anyway. The Keeper's tried her keychain crap on me, Hobbes has lectured me more times than many professors manage in a whole semester of lecturing, the Fatman has tried to teach me the errors of my ways--they have all in their own ways tried to redeem me too. But them? They've also recognized that actually, no, I'm not in need of redemption. And me? I've guess I've learned a few slightly more socially respectable ways to earn my keep.

Oh, hell. Do we have to go through that again? Just because I got a frickin' third strike and showed up on AOL that last time, now everyone decides to remember who the hell I am and wonder why the hell I'm not still locked up for life. And they always remember at exactly the wrong time, too. And, for the record, that third strike? Not my fault. I totally was not guilty of what they were planning to put me away for. Thieving, sure, but not--that. Jeez. Yeah, I've been in prison already. Not pleasant. Not pretty. Not my most favorite place in the whole world to be. And I am never, repeat, never going back. No matter what cracked-out plans somebody comes up with, or how bad the itch to steal gets again, or if I run into Manny again and beat the crap out of him. He already got me in jail once, I'm not giving him any favors and letting him put me in there a second time on an assault charge. So, yeah. Prison. Whoop-de-frickin-doo.

Usually I'm being forced into something, not out of it. The Fatman's always putting me onto cases with Hobbes that I'd rather avoid like they were a plague of locusts; Eberts is always forcing me into doing paperwork; Hobbes is always forcing me to do things for the job that I would rather just not do; Claire's always forcing me into taking tests, being poked, letting her take my blood. I'd walk away but, y'know, none of them will let me. There have been a couple times, though. When I really, really wanted to do something and they wouldn't let me. Wanted to take down the bad guy, wanted to get involved, but the gland was working up (as usual; y'know, the least my brother could do is *fix* the damned piece of crap before he went and got himself killed...okay, there's a lot of other things he could have done, including just taking the gland out, but it's all moot anyway), or they didn't think they could trust me to do the right thing, or whatever. And it was always the strangest feeling because--because on the one hand, I was hurt they wouldn't let me do what I do best (get in trouble, basically), and on the other I was embarrassed and angry because I actually wanted to get involved, and I just knew the Fatman would use that against me come the next time I said "Oh hell no." (He did, of course. He always does.) The moral of the story? My life is strange. Yeah, I know, so what else is new.

*blinks a lot* I'm...pretty sure I'd never been asked that question before. But I was watching one of those zombie movies, y'know, Night of the Living Dead or something, with Hobbes the other night. It was two in the morning, it was the only thing on that wasn't an infomercial or Loveboat reruns (Hobbes wanted to watch those reruns, I know he did even if he didn't want to admit it, but I *refused*), neither of us could sleep and he'd somehow ended up at my apartment. And he goes and asks me, after stealing another bite of popcorn (he'd *told* me he didn't want any, and then he kept eating out of mine. Hmph). So I told him. "Get an axe," I said, "a flame-thrower--do you have any shotguns?--and camp out in a grocery store." "I wouldn't give you my shotguns," Hobbes retorted, and when he reached for the popcorn I slapped his hand. "No, but I'd expect you to bring them with you to the grocery store," I told him. "Oh." Hobbes sat up on the couch a little. "You'd really spend the zombie apocalypse with me?" I shrugged and munched on popcorn. "Who else could I trust to get our asses through it?" "That's so nice of you." Bobby honestly sounded like he could've cried. "We'd have to get Claire too. She could probably come up with some chemical concoction to melt them or something." "Bleach," I said laconically. "They sell lots of bleach at grocery stores." By the end of the movie, we'd finished the popcorn and knew exactly how we'd handle our own zombie apocalypse. Considering all the other crap I've had to deal with in the past year or two? I'm kinda surprised we haven't had one of those yet. At least for once when it happens we'll have a plan.

Are you an only child? Write about your siblings or lack thereof. Heh. Uh...yeah. How's that for an awkward question. I'm an only child--now. I sure as hell didn't grow up that way. My brother Kevin, he was a couple years older than me. Not much, but it was enough. I suppose I was a classic baby brother, clowning around, getting in trouble, trying to draw attention to myself by goofing off. Whatever. Sometimes it worked. Kev, Kev was a genius. Straight up, 100% pure, grade A genius. I mean, he was thinking about genetic coding at the tender age of twelve, I swear. Now, me, I'm smart. I'm even on occasion clever. But I am no frickin' genius. But I was smarter than my brother. Even he said so. Kevin did something stupid. He trusted somebody he shouldn't have--and I don't mean me, though I easily could have. And he died. He died in my arms and I had no chance whatsoever to save him. So now I'm an only child. What do you think? What do I think? What do I think? I think it's the stupidest, crappiest, dumbest plan we've come up with yet, but who the hell cares what I think. It relies on Chrysalis believing us--which, yeah, that happens so often--and it relies on split-second timing--which, okay, sometimes Hobbes and I are beautiful at the timing, but sometimes...not so much--and it relies on Monroe acting like she's going to the other side. Which, when she heard *that* part of the plan? I'm kinda surprised she didn't shoot Bobby right there and then, come to think of it. Like I said, Chrysalis has to believe us. Monroe's joining them does not exactly fit easily into something they'll find believable. This is so going to end in tears. Tears of pain. Probably mine. Hopefully not tears of pain because my invisible ass has been shot, but I'm not going to hold my breath on that one. I only hope Claire is on hand to stitch me up again.

Uh. I have a rat. I know, not exactly your typical pet, but--hey, other people have rats. Of course, mine's been a little genetically engineered, and he started out as part of a lab experiment in invisibility. I couldn't really stand to see us both being lab rats anymore, though, so I took him from Claire's little basement hideaway. Hey, she's got me to experiment and run tests on now. Why should she care? (She does, though. At least a little. She still occasionally gets annoyed with me for stealing him.) I wouldn't want another pet, though. Claire's got all kinds of other critters in the lab--some of which I have no clue why and thank god she got rid of the spider, and she seems perfectly fine taking care of all of them. Me, though, I'd hate all that responsibility. I think I've safely proven I'm kinda crap with having too much responsibility. The usual reasons not to have a pet totally apply to me--I'm rarely home, I wouldn't be able to give the little guy--whatever species he might be--the proper care he deserves, yadda yadda. More unusual reasons apply too, like my life being in constant danger and I don't even want to think what I would do if I went quicksilver mad around it. (Oh, crap.) So no pets for me in the near future, probably, besides my rat. Though I think, maybe, a few years down the road? Maybe I'll get a fish. Yeah.

Okay, see now, I hate it when I come into the middle of things. Like, take yesterday for instance. I slouch into work at my usual time when not in the middle of something big (and good God you do *not* want to hear how often Hobbes has complained about my usual time of coming into work, but seriously, what does he expect from an ex-thief?), and I made my way to the Official's office because that's what I usually do--I go to his office, or the Keep's lab, or Bobby's office. Actually, I don't have an office. This is why I have to go bug everybody else. Do any of them think of that? No. I bet if they got me an office, I would get into way less trouble than I do currently snooping around in everybody else's business. ...Okay, I suck at lying. This is why I was a thief and not a conman. Anyway. So I go to the Fatman's office, and I can hear him and Eberts in there, and a couple other voices, so I immediately do the quicksilver shimmer because, hey, it's not like anybody around here tells me anything of their own volition. (Yeah, there really is no point in giving me an office; I'd never hang out there anyway.) The problem is, of course, the doors are closed. And just because I'm invisible doesn't mean I can walk through walls. I should ask the Keep about that sometime. Huh. Right, so, I don't knock on the door because I've used that trick before and Eberts has a really good memory. I'm leaning up against the door, trying to listen in and think about how I can get myself in there when the door opens, I almost fall on top of somebody, and Eberts starts stammering. The Fatman bellows, I push myself away, the new guy looks confused, Eberts ushers him out blushing like a fire engine, and practically before the door even hits Eberts on the ass on his way out the Official is yelling at me. So, the point of all this? I'm up to my neck in Canadian terrorists--again--Eberts is doing unnatural things to my paycheck, Hobbes is sulking because he thinks I got all this secret information about the mission that he didn't, and all because I got into the conversation at the last minute. Well, no, I would've been stuck with the Canadian terrorists no matter what but it would have been nice to be asked first, rather than land on the Canadian diplomat and scare the crap out of him.

I...I don't want to talk about it. (I'm supposed to talk about it. That's what she said, right? Share a little more, it might help. Frickin' key chain crap.) I have the same dream, a lot of nights. Not every night, not every every night, but...a lot. It's not a dream, not in the usual way, like where you're naked in front of your high school English class, it's a memory. My brother's death. It's on my mind a lot, y'know? I mean, he was my brother, he died in my arms, it was messy. You know. *scratches head* Sometimes I dream in quicksilver. Sometimes I dream about Simon Cole. Sometimes I dream about killing Arnaud, my hands on his throat, nice'n'slow'n'steady. (Yeah, but what about last night?) I really don't want to talk about it. I--I dreamt I killed Kevin. My brother, I was the one who shot him, he didn't--I didn't pick him up, he just fell to the ground, all covered in his own blood and died. That's not the way it happened. I've never dreamed it like that before. It was in quicksilver, too, which--huh, yeah, ain't that symbolic. You don't need to be a frickin' Joseph with a frickin' technicolor dreamcoat to figure out what that dream means, you know? All part of my massive, honest fear that someday I'm gonna snap completely and kill and hurt and kill innocent people. There's probably some sibling messiness in there too, but whatever, it's all standard, textbook psychoanalytic babble, right? Easily understood and explained away. It doesn't make me feel any less uncomfortable. After that--after last night? I almost prefer the standard dream-memory about my brother dying in my arms. And that? Is pretty messed up.

I've drawn so many lines around myself that I'm kinda surprised I don't look like a mime in a box. (Hate mimes. Even after that one I almost killed. Oh, crap.) I've done it all my life. Stupid coping mechanisms, right? Drew a line between myself and my aunt and uncle, between me and Kev. And when he crossed that line, he ended up getting killed and I ended up getting an extra gland in my head. ...He would have died anyway. Arnaud wasn't about to let that formula get away from him; my brother was going to die, and I would have been none the wiser if I hadn't agreed to his stupid desperate plan to keep me out of jail. Huh. *shakes self* I drew lines between me and the Official, between me and Hobbes, me and the Keeper. (Monroe, she drew lines between herself and all of us.) And most of those lines? They're gone. Eroded through long exposure. Hell, some days I even almost trust the Fatman. (Okay, that's a load of crap, but whatever.) All those lines, just gone. It's scarier this way--I feel a lot more vulnerable, all these people so close around me--but it's also, I dunno...nice. Somehow comforting. *groans* I hope Claire and Bobby never finds this.

I don't understand how this Agency can exist. No, seriously. I have no clue when it got started--it's been around at least 30 years, though--I have no clue why it got started--it must've been something to do with the Cold War; I bet everyone wanted their own super secret spying agency back then--and I really have no clue how it's lasted so long. I think they used to maybe have more money--from what the Catevari said, they did a lot of experiments back in the day--but, seriously, when the Berlin Wall came down, these guys should have been one of the first super secret spying agencies to shut down. It's all Eberts can do week after week to keep the photocopier running, the electricity turned on, and--oh yeah--me in counteragent supply. Hell, I'm surprised every time I cash my pay check that it doesn't bounce. I didn't think that kind of creative bookkeeping was allowed anymore, even in government. Then again, Eberts came from the IRS; he probably has a lot of practice. Seriously, I don't get it. But I'm stuck with it until I get this gland out of my head so I just keep praying that Eberts continues to find ways to keep the phones working.

What was the longest day of your life? Huh. I've had a lot of really long days (in such a short life)--lots and lots of all-nighters and not getting any sleep for, like, 48 hours or whatever. Yeah, I've done all that. I think the longest day of my life, though, was one of the ones for which I spent the shortest amount of time awake. As an adult, anyway. I mean, I really liked to sleep a lot as a kid. Anyway. It was the day Kevin and his gang of scientists (seriously, these people were a gang) operated on me. Longest day of my life, it really was. I mean, my brother sprung me out of jail by making me his guinea pig; I was not exactly sanguine about the whole experience going into it, y'know what I mean? So he gets me out, and he picks me up in this stupid old van with a bunch of federal goons in black suits, and--the whole thing is ridiculous. I'm nervous, right, because Kevin won't tell me a damned thing, and I'm cranky, I admit, because I can't take any of it seriously when I'm stuck in the back of a van that's from the '70s or '80s sometime. What the hell was I getting myself into? Why the hell wouldn't my brother tell me? How bad was this crap, anyway? That drive out to the lab was fricking endless. And then Kevin takes me into the lab (which, by the way, was way more high-tech and cool-looking than the van) and introduces me to his gaggle of scientists (they were a gaggle and a gang, alright?), including Arnaud, and then--and then I'm out. Anesthetized. Pretty much, anyway, for the operation, and-- It was awful. It didn't take my brother long to get me out of jail, just a few days, but I've never been all that great at waiting, and that day, the actual day that he got me out and put me under--it really, really sucked. Endless, like I said. What do you hope for? I hope to get this gland out of my head. I hope to maybe see my dad again sometime, try to get a little more information out of him about his life. I hope to figure out what the hell is going on with my life and take some more control over it. Every day I hope Bobby's taken his pills, that the Keeper is in a good mood, that Monroe is in a good mood, that the Fish doesn't feel like toying with me, that Eberts can cook the books enough to keep the electricity and water running. Sometimes I hope that Arnaud dies with my hands around his scrawny neck, other times that he just dies, however I have to go about making it happen. I hope I can see my Aunt Celia around the holidays, and maybe my grandma too, if she'd like that. I hope that I can pick up this particular hair product that I really like but is kinda hard to find. I have a lot of hopes. We all do, right? Hey, man, you asked.

Seriously? Do I have to answer this? I've done some seriously stupid and embarrassing crap in my life, the majority of it while sober, and cataloguing everything will just be more embarrassing. Actually, just trying to figure out the most embarrassing thing will be more embarrassing. And I think I'm beginning to hate typing out that word. I had sex with Allainora and got, like, the sci-fi nanobot version of an STD. That ranks pretty high up there. Of course, then she died, which sucked a lot, but apparently it doesn't take away from the embarrassment factor. Oh, oh, I got kidnapped by an acupuncturist once because my back was killing me and she found out I could turn invisible. How's that for really pathetically embarrassing? And let's not even talk about the many and myriad ways having an invisibility gland at the wrong moment can make for some really awkward and difficult-to-explain conversations. Those are all just in the past year or less. I refuse to go into the stupid crap I pulled in my previous life.

*starts snickering* *turns into chortles* *eventually guffaws* Sorry. Sorry, sorry, sorry. *catches breath* That's just--that's really funny. Really, really, really funny. I am a spy. Sort of, technically. I mean, yes, I am a spy. One of the worst-paid spies for the worst-funded government Agency ever. I have been for about a year and before that I was a thief. A cat burglar. Finest kind. Actually, I kinda sucked at it, but we're not talking about that career choice today. So, *do* I make a good spy? I think I do. My partner, Bobby Hobbes, often doesn't think so. The Fatman, my boss, I guess he does, at least sometimes, because he hasn't taken the gland out of my brain yet. I know how these guys think, a lot of the time (and the rest of the time, Bobby knows how they think. I am not gonna talk about how good a team we make). And I'm good at figuring ways out of things. It helps that I have the Q-gland, of course; there is a lot of crap I do that I could not do otherwise without that gland. So. Some stupid mistakes, some--oh, minor brain surgery, the death of my brother, and suddenly I'm a spy in the employ of the United States government. Hey, it's a living.

Which mess?  I always seem to be cleaning up messes.  Ever since Kevin stuck this gland in my brain, my life is one long series of mops and buckets.  

Yeah, okay, granted, a lot of the messes I've been cleaning up the past year or two are my own, I have to admit.  I keep screwing up, it seems like--and, hey, my entire life has been one perpetual screw-up, pretty much, but lately I've been...I've been taking more responsibility for my actions and trying to clean up after myself.

Yeah, yeah, keychain crap.  I can blame Claire for that.  And Bobby, and hell, even the Fatman.  Being chained to an unnamed Agency with an invisibility gland in your head kinda forces you to face some things you never thought you'd have to face.  Or at least, it did in my case.

They're not all my messes.  Letting Claire's contagious friend go, that was my fault; picking back up with my old partner Liz, that was mine too.  Kevin's putting the gland in my brain in the first place?  And then refusing to tell Claire how to take it out?  The Catevari, Arnaud de Fehrn's very existence, not to mention Chrysalis?  These were not my messes, but they are mine to deal with.

Uh...weirdly enough, it actually involves both my parents. It's one of the few memories I have of my dad, in fact. I don't know how old I was; two or three maybe? We were at a park. Spring or summer, probably; it was sunny and green and I don't remember if it was hot or not, but I never remember things like summer heat from when I was a kid. Maybe I didn't notice it back then. Anyway, we were at the park, and I remember my mom was watching Kevin as he went up and down one of the slides. She was laughing, and I think Kev was too (yeah, I know; I'm shocked he knew how to laugh or even play on a slide, but I guess he must have taken the occasional day off from being a genius kid). My dad was pushing me on one of those baby-swings, the ones that hold you in place, you know? Up and down. I can remember squealing in delight. Like I said, it's one of the few memories I have of my dad. It's one of the few memories I have of my whole family together like that, and happy. For all I know, I completely made it up later, fantasizing about having some kind of perfect childhood or some crap like that. But I...I kinda hope it is a real memory.

It used to be, in my old career, that I was the bad news. Nowadays, I spend an awful lot of time telling people, "Uh, yeah, sorry, but..." I had to tell my Aunt Celia that my brother Kevin was dead. My relationship with my family has always been pretty--crappy; none of us have been very good at being a family. When Kevin died, I--I didn't tell anyone. I didn't-- There are things you're supposed to do, right, when somebody you care about dies. You take care of the body, and you notify the rest of the family, and you hold a funeral and people for some reason give you casseroles, crap like that. At least, that's what other people have told me, and I've seen that kind of thing on tv, and I think that's what happened when my mom died when I was a little kid. At least, I remember a lot of casseroles and a lot of old people I'd never seen before wearing black and patting me on the head. I pretty much hated it. I didn't do any of that for Kevin. I left him lying there in his blood for Arnaud to find and I ran. I mean, yeah, I kinda had to run, since I was in the early stages of quicksilver madness and Arnaud was after my ass--or rather, my brain--but, jeez, it's a crappy way to treat your dead older brother. I buried him, eventually--actually, the Agency did--but, hell, it was screwed up. And I never told Aunt Celia what happened. She'd raised Kev'n'me, and after the Official found me and I got saddled working for the Agency with Hobbes, I just--I never contacted her. I just sort of shut down anything that had to do with Kevin, maybe; I dunno, I don't understand grief and the way it operates. So when I finally went to visit her in her little senior living community thing, and she said I'd just missed seeing Kevin, it was kind of a shock, you know? It wasn't Kevin, of course; it was some stupid plot of Arnaud's, but after it was all done and I re-buried my brother, I finally went back to Celia to tell her what had happened. I never want to have to do something like that again. Aunt Celia isn't a bad old girl; she was always a bit--distant, with me, when I was a kid, but she was my mother's older sister and she loved me, and she loved Kevin, and having to tell her that her only other nephew was dead was pretty painful. She hadn't expected it, would never have expected geeky-scientist-Kevin to die so young, and I couldn't even give her all the details about how and why it happened. I've had to tell a number of people somebody died, or something happened that was going to really, really ruin their day. I made my friend Bobby give up being a genius, and I've had to tell Claire an awful lot how much I screwed up and in what ways. But the worst time of it I've had was talking to Aunt Celia.

Dude, I get more flak about my hair--what is up with that? Seriously? It's my hair. Leave it alone, people. I like my hair. With hair like mine, you kinda have to love or hate it, and I decided a long time ago to love it. Kevin got the reasonable hair genes. I got the floppy and wild hair genes. I'm cool with that now. Took years of therapy. Ha. Hobbes makes fun of all the products I have in my bathroom, like he expects that I use them all every day or something. Claire found it hilarious, the first time she saw my bathroom; said I had more stuff than she did, and I just told her I could give her tips if she wanted. (Yeah, that one kinda backfired on me.) The Fatman used to try to tell me I need a haircut, I didn't look like a proper field agent in service to the US government, and I just told him to cut the crap. If he's going to keep me chained to his Agency, then he should damned well get used to me looking however the hell I want to look. I think Eberts is a little freaked out by my hair. But then, that's Eberts.

I like my digs. It's why I keep refusing to move, even though the Fatman--and Hobbes, for that matter--keep telling me I should find a new apartment, what with all the people and groups after my invisible ass. But I like my studio. It's not too small, it's got a pretty decent kitchen area with some good counter space, there's lots of light, and the bathroom is totally sweet. There's enough room for me and my stuff and my books, and that works for me. I hate moving. I hate boxing up my crap and hauling it all over town and unpacking it. It smells like those damned plastic peanuts--even if I haven't used any--and something's inevitably broken, and at least three things are inevitably lost, never to be seen again. It took me a long time to find this place, and I'm not going to find another place like it easily. I've moved around enough in my life, had enough instability, you know? I like having some place to go back to where I can crash and be comfortable. Hobbes and the Official, I'm just not sure they get that.

When I'm invisible... (Yeah, you don't know many people who can actually say that and mean it, do you?) When I'm invisible, it's almost like seeing in black and white. It's more like--like varying shades of white, and black, and silver (hey, it's not called quicksilver for nothing, right?). I wonder if maybe that's the way some people dream? I used to always dream in color, before I got the gland. And I still do, most of the time. But sometimes... It's a little weird. The world's a little, um, flatter, not quite as three-dimensional. It took my depth perception a while to get used to it, too; at first I had some problems with things being closer than I expected, or a little bit more to one side. (Kevin had a field day with crap like that, back at the lab when he ran me through three million and one tests.) And I think there's a bit of synaesthesia going on there too, or maybe it's just because my core body temperature does get lower when I'm invisible because the whole world feels colder when I'm seeing in quicksilver vision. (And no, it can't just be my body temp 'cause I feel that way even when I've only quicksilvered my eyes; I still feel colder...I suppose I should mention that to Claire one of these days. Probably. Unless I mentioned it to Kevin, way back when? I probably did. He asked a lot of questions back then.) Yeah. I wouldn't recommend the whole black and white vision thing to people. It's just weird.

"Everything passes. Nobody gets anything for keeps. And that's how we've got to live." Haruki Murakami. Those are some of the truest words ever spoken. Seriously, my life is emblematic of the fact that everything dies. My dad skipped out; my mom died; my brother died; I was a thief for a significant portion of my life, taking away those things that were often the most precious to other people; and someday, probably sooner than I'd like to think about, I'm gonna die. And not just me--Hobbes, my partner; hell, even Claire, my Keeper. We've got dangerous jobs here; even the Official and Eberts aren't immune to the dangers. I've lost so many relationships over the years. More than that, I've lost my freedom more than once--I've been in jail; I'm in a strange sort of prison now, due to the gland in my head. I lost my first set of lucky lockpicking tools; I had my third set confiscated by the police. A lot of my stuff from when I was a little kid, really small, got lost in the shuffle after my mom died and Kevin and I moved in with our aunt and uncle. Stuff happens. You lose things. You lose people. There's nothing you can do about it, just make it last as long as you can and make it the most enjoyable, the most memorable, that you can. And to look at it another way, like Mason Cooley said, every farewell combines loss - and new freedom.

I know I've probably spent more wee small hours and 3 a.m.s awake than your typical person, unless your typical person is a college student or something. I mean, I do some of my best work at that time of day. Both in my previous career and my current profession. It's a weird time to be awake--you see the other cars on the road, lights on in other people's houses or apartments or at the grocery store, and you wonder what the hell they could be doing. Nobody's functioning at that time of day if they can help it, after all. It's a weird time to be awake, and when I'm awake at that time, I'm wide awake. Adrenaline pumping, you know? I mean, I'm usually running, either as a perp or chasing a perp. I haven't had to do too many stakeouts, and when I have they usually seem to break right around three in the morning, so that just when I'm about ready to drop off, or I'm smacking Bobby because he's snoring again, something happens, and we're in the middle of a car chase, or running down an alley, or something. I like being awake in the wee small hours. The air's fresher, even in the city; there's not as many people around and they're not gonna mess with you because they don't want you to mess with them. And it always kinda reminds me of junior high, high school, being out past curfew, that dangerous little thrill of excitement. Yeah, it's stupid, I know, but so what? My line of work, you really kinda have to be some sort of adrenaline junkie.

"Do not the most moving moments of our lives find us without words?" Marcel Marceau. Yeah...I think I'd agree with that. The most moving, the most--emotional. When my mother died, when my brother died. When Bobby woke up, after Claire gave him the, um, antidote? The one that took away his super-genius gene resequencing...I had all kinds of words, when I was trying to persuade him to give us the information, when I was trying every single damned thing I could think of to make sure he lived and was himself again. But later after he woke up--nothing either of us could have said would have been right. Adequate. It's those moments, man. Those really big moments, when any noise would be wrong. I think I remember screaming, or crying, or something, when my brother died. I remember his blood all over me, I remember feeling as if his skin was going cold on me right there. But I don't remember any sound at all. It was like a vacuum, maybe, all noise flattened out, thinned to nothing. Maybe the noise was too big for me to hear. I think...I think it was the same when I was a kid. I'm pretty sure Kevin was yelling, when they told us our mom was dead, screaming at them that they were liars. I remember crying, even though I didn't really understand what was going on. But it's all visual, no sound, those memories. No sound. No words.

Headlines. The last headline I made--it even made it to AOL--continues to haunt me. Which really sucks because a) that incident was a total lie and b) it continues to screw me over because, hey, according to that, I'm supposed to be in jail for life and not a secret agent for a really stupid underfunded government Agency who can incidentally turn invisible. That was the last headline I made. Anything since the Official has copped it, just saying it was the government's good deeds overall or some crap like that, or smothered it, or in some way or other made sure my name was in no way involved. Covering his ass, of course; and covering mine, in a way, I suppose, since it probably wouldn't be a good idea to spill the beans about the government's secret invisible agent. I suppose I should just be grateful I'm not in prison for life; I guess I should just be glad to do a good job and take down the bad guys and have the respect and gratitude of my peers. But that's total crap, isn't it? The bad guys are either out to get me personally, or if they're actually bad can be something of a gray issue; and I totally don't get any respect. I'd rather show up on AOL again, for, like, saving the world from the Canadian terrorists or something, thanks. Sleeping on the couch. I, uh, I fell asleep on Hobbes' couch once. Okay, yeah, no big deal; he's my partner and he's a friend, right? But the dude does not invite people over. His private life is totally his own and we do not get to find out about it unless he says so. (Yeah, that whole case with the Chinese and me turning him invisible so they'd think he was the guy they were after? That was a real eye-opener, lemme tell you.) His couch? Very much a part of his private life. But this, this was just after that whole thing with the super-genius drug, and stuff was kinda hinky between us because of it, awkward for the partnership, y'know? Even if we tried to act like everything was cool, there was still this underlying base line of weirdness. So Bobby invited me over to watch the game with him, and we were just sitting on his couch, talking crap about the game afterward. We'd both had a lot of beer, and it was pretty late, and Bobby went to throw some of the cans away and I...kinda fell asleep on his couch. I seriously didn't mean to; I just closed my eyes for a second and then woke up, like, four hours later. Hobbes had thrown a blanket over me. I'd drooled on it. I didn't mention that to him when I handed it to him the next morning. But everything after that was fine. And Bobby's fallen asleep on my couch a couple times since then, when a case had us working really late and I told him not to bother going home. I mean, hey, it's not like I really have a private life anymore to keep secret from my co-workers.

A lie? That my parents told me? I'm guessing you're not thinking of one of the standard Santa-Claus-really-does-exist lies here, right? Okay, try this one on for size: my dad lied completely about what he did. Who he was. Everything. Not that he ever really directly told us the lies. Everyone else had to because he was never actually around. He was a thief, a professional liar by trade, a con artist. Runs in the family, right? It's in my freakin' blood. But it's worse than that; it actually runs deeper than that and I really do think it might run in the family after all. Because dad's criminal record was a fake. A dodge, another lie, a total fabrication to cover up what he really did for a living. Professional assassin in the employ of the United States government. Yup, like father like son; that's my dad. That's my entire family. All of us, somehow, working for The Man. Okay, Kev was a scientist and I'm not an assassin, but still. The parallels and chain of coincidences is a little too creepy to be truly coincidental, don't you think? That was the major lie of my childhood. There were lots of them, of course, but that's the one that I didn't even realize was a lie until a couple months ago. My dad wasn't even the one to finally tell me the truth.

Uh...well, there's Allianora. Or, well, I mean, I suppose any, um, romantic relationship involves at least a little seduction, right? Right? I know I was totally trying to seduce Casey, charm her and keep her interested in me long enough that I could get to know her better. And it worked, you know? It worked for a whole year before it all went to pot and-and I lost her. But that's not really the sort of thing people think about when they hear the word seduction. Allianora...she was a consummate seducer. She played me, man; she'd been playing me the entire time I knew her. Not long, not really, but she tried every thing she could to get under my skin and she finally did. ...But any seduction takes two people, doesn't it? And me, she pissed me off but she fascinated me too and I wanted to get under her skin. It was kinda inevitable, really, what with both of us being experimented on, modified, being freaks of nature. Okay, maybe it wasn't inevitable, but she *got* to me, and I guess I got to her too. So there you have it, the one time I really got seduced. And, I guess, maybe did a little seducing of my own.

Impossible? Impossible? *snorts, throws arms out wide* I am the ultimate in impossible, man. My life is the most unlikely set of circumstances and coincidences you are ever likely to see. Condemned to life in prison for a crime I really, really did not commit; genius brother scientist springs me in exchange for me participating in his experiment; join a nonexistent federal Agency with no name and no money; and, oh yeah, I'm the fricking original Invisible Man with a gland in my head that turns me insane every few days if I don't take a counteragent. I've been almost killed by Canadian terrorists, I've had a previous invisible agent take over my brain and allowed my (dead, mind you) brother to do the same, I've helped a ghost and I've hung out with a water spirit. I'm telling you, my life is just one long chain of unpredictable and unlikely events these days, and I think the only way it's going to end any time soon is if I end up dead. Not that I want or plan to end up dead anytime soon, mind you. But I think at this point my life is so completely screwed that even if I got this gland out of my head? My life would still be impossible.

Sometimes I wonder what Liz is up to these days. She--I guess you could say she was my mentor in all things crime-related. She taught me everything I know about picking locks, disarming alarms, and sneaking around in black. We parted ways...a while back. Or, well, she disappeared on me, but whatever, right? I saw her again, though, not too long ago--after this whole mess that is my life now started up, in fact. She asked me to work a job with her, and who was I to say no? I mean, c'mon, lifelong calling here, and I'd missed being a thief. A lot. A whoooole lot. So of course I said yes. Big mistake, I know. It went from bad to worse, when I found out what we were stealing and for whom, and then Bobby freaking caught me and I had to endure everyone's disappointment and anger, and then, to top it all off, I had to try to save the day without using the invisibility gland. And in the end, Liz got her money and disappeared again anyway. Nah, it's cool. I couldn't go back to that life after all, I realized, and Liz--well, I guess I'd finally outgrown her.

There's...a lot of things I'm afraid of. Dying, for one; killing, for another. Going permanently quicksilver mad, losing all inhibitions. Spiders. I am deathly afraid of spiders, man. Seriously. It's not funny. There's a lot of things I used to be afraid of that I'm not anymore. You know, when I was a kid? I was afraid of the dark. I find that pretty funny now, as an adult. And there's things I'm afraid of now that I would never have even dreamed to be afraid of, before. I'm afraid that someday I'm going to wake up in a white padded cell with no memory of how or why I ended up there, beyond the knowledge that I did something truly terrible. And that's--that's not something I used to ever consider, back when I was just a plain ol' cat burglar. A lot of the time, I don't let it get to me. I'm too busy being pissed off with the Fatman, or trying to cajole the Keep into telling me if she's made any new discoveries, or arguing with Hobbes, or trying not to get on Monroe's bad side (or Eberts for that matter--I never want him to screw up my paperwork again). A lot of the time, my fears are more immediate--"Oh crap, somebody's shooting at me" kind of thing, and that sort of fear takes a lot of precedence over the existential, long-term terror that makes up the majority of my nights and some of my days. I try not to let it get to me. But there's a reason I hate that damned padded white cell.

Then what the hell are you supposed to do when your reality is insane? It's not a response I can control, you know. It just happens. I'd say "like clockwork," except that it isn't even as predictable as that. But it is...business as usual. I hate business as usual. I don't think it's an appropriate response; I think it's a frigging inescapable response when you're in my shoes. Screw reality; I go insane. Regularly. At least once a week. At least they haven't had to put me in the padded room lately. Lately. I want some sanity in my life again. I want not to wake up with an invisibility gland curled up in my head like a tiny little time bomb that goes off every few days giving me red eyes, voices in the back of my head, and the meanest temper you've ever seen. I want to be normal again--as normal as I ever was, which, granted, wasn't very normal, but at least it was my life. My reality is that I go insane. And there's nothin' I can do about it.

Well, it sure as hell ain't me. Honestly? I'm not sure anyone is winning. I think we're all at an impasse--right now, at least. And maybe just over the long haul. Guys like Chrysalis, or Arnaud, or the Chinese--the people trying to grab me, use me, use my gland--sometimes they get ahead of us. Of me. Sometimes they get a hold of me, sometimes they get away before we can snatch them. And they always think they're winning anyway, that they're so damned superior and in control. I don't believe 'em. I don't think anybody's in control. Not the Fatman, not Chrysalis, not even No-Name guy. I think they all just wished they were in control. And therefore winning. Me, I know better. After the way things have gone down in my life--after the choices I have made and after the choices I never got to make--I know there's no such thing as control or winning. We're at an impasse, all of us. In balance, or something, over the long term--so one minute Chrysalis seems to be in the lead, the next, I dunno, those freakin' Free Quebec Canadian terrorists. But we're not, none of us. We're just...pretending we know what we're doing.
